paragraphs.text:
%md

# Practical 9 Part 1: Spark Dataframe

msg.data: Practical 9 Part 1: Spark Dataframe

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Learning Objectives

By the end of this lesson, you should be able to 

* Use Spark dataframe to perform data processing operations

msg.data:
Learning Objectives

By the end of this lesson, you should be able to

  • Use Spark dataframe to perform data processing operations

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Copy data into HDFS

msg.data: Copy data into HDFS

paragraphs.text:
%sh

hdfs dfs -mkdir -p /data
hdfs dfs -put ~/git/itd353/p9_dataframe/data/Covid-19-SG.csv /data/Covid-19-SG.csv

msg.data: put: `/data/Covid-19-SG.csv': File exists
ExitValue: 1

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Starting with a Spark Session

To get started, we need to load a Spark Sessoin from the configuration.

msg.data:
Starting with a Spark Session

To get started, we need to load a Spark Sessoin from the configuration.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.sql import SparkSession

sparkmaster = "spark://pop-t540.localdomain:7077" # change this according to your machine domain name, check out https://localhost:8080
hadoopmaster = "hdfs://127.0.0.1:9000"
sparkSession = SparkSession.builder.master(sparkmaster).appName("Spark Dataframe").getOrCreate()

%md 

## Reading data

We read from a CSV file located in the HDFS.

msg.data:
Reading data

We read from a CSV file located in the HDFS.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
df = sparkSession.read.option("header", "true").option("delimiter",",").option("inferSchema", "true").csv(hadoopmaster + "/data/Covid-19-SG.csv")

%md 

To take a brief look at the dataframe content, we use the `.show()` method.

msg.data: To take a brief look at the dataframe content, we use the .show() method.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
df.show(5)

%md
To find out the schema of the dataframe we use the `.printSchema()` method.

msg.data: To find out the schema of the dataframe we use the .printSchema() method.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
df.printSchema()

msg.data:
root
 |-- Date: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Daily Confirmed : integer (nullable = true)
 |-- Daily Discharged: integer (nullable = true)
 |-- Discharged to Isolation: integer (nullable = true)
 |-- Daily Deaths: integer (nullable = true)
 |-- Tested positive demise: integer (nullable = true)
 |-- Daily Imported: integer (nullable = true)
 |-- Daily Local transmission: integer (nullable = true)
 |-- Local cases residing in dorms MOH report: integer (nullable = true)
 |-- Local cases not residing in doms MOH report: integer (nullable = true)

paragraphs.text:
%md 

## Column Selection

To select a certain columns, we use `.select()` method.

msg.data:
Column Selection

To select a certain columns, we use .select() method.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
dfDailyConfirmed = df.select("Date", "Daily Confirmed ")

dfDailyConfirmed

msg.data: DataFrame[Date: string, Daily Confirmed : int]

paragraphs.text:
%md ## Exercise 1 Note that it does not show the data, it returns a new dataframe. To show the data, we can apply the `.Show()` method to the new dataframe. Call the `show()` function to show the first 5 rows in the data frame.
[Show Hint]
```python dfDailyConfirmed.show(5) ```

msg.data:
Exercise 1

Note that it does not show the data, it returns a new dataframe. To show the data, we can apply the .Show() method to the new dataframe. Call the show() function to show the first 5 rows in the data frame.

[Show Hint]
dfDailyConfirmed.show(5)

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# TODO:

%md

We can use `.select()` apply some simple modification to the projected columns.

msg.data: We can use .select() apply some simple modification to the projected columns.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.sql.functions import concat, col, lit

df.select(concat(df["Date"], lit("-2020")).alias("Date"), df["Daily Confirmed "]+ 0.0).show(5)

%md

## Column Conversion

Some times we want to "modify" the column without dropping the rest of the columns, to do that, we use `.withColumn()` method.

msg.data:
Column Conversion

Some times we want to “modify” the column without dropping the rest of the columns, to do that, we use .withColumn() method.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

dfDateWithYear = df.withColumn("Date", concat(col("Date"),lit("-2020")))

dfDateWithYear.show(5)

%md 

There more predefined dataframe functions in `org.apache.spark.sql.functions`

For instance, we can use the `to_date()` sql function to format the date string to date object.

msg.data:
There more predefined dataframe functions in org.apache.spark.sql.functions

For instance, we can use the to_date() sql function to format the date string to date object.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
from pyspark.sql.functions import concat, col, lit, to_date
dfDateParsed = dfDateWithYear.withColumn("Date", to_date(col("Date"), "dd-MMM-yyyy"))

dfDateParsed.show(5)

%md 

## Row Filtering

To filter rows from a dataframe based on a boolean condition, we use `.filter()` method.

msg.data:
Row Filtering

To filter rows from a dataframe based on a boolean condition, we use .filter() method.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

dfAfterApril5 = dfDateParsed.filter(col("Date") >= to_date(lit("05-Apr-2020"), "dd-MMM-yyyy"))

dfAfterApril5.show(5)

%md ## Exercise 2 Can you fiter out rows whose `Daily Deaths` is greater than 0?
[Show Hint]
```python dfWithDailyDeaths = dfDateParsed.filter(col("Daily Deaths") > 0) dfWithDailyDeaths.show(5) ```

msg.data:
Exercise 2

Can you fiter out rows whose Daily Deaths is greater than 0?

[Show Hint]
dfWithDailyDeaths = dfDateParsed.filter(col("Daily Deaths") > 0)

dfWithDailyDeaths.show(5)

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

# TODO

%md

## Grouping and Aggregation

To group rows we can use `groupBy()` method. Aggregation can be applied to groups.

msg.data:
Grouping and Aggregation

To group rows we can use groupBy() method. Aggregation can be applied to groups.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
from pyspark.sql.functions import concat, col, lit, month

dfWithMonth = dfDateParsed.withColumn("Month", month(col("Date")))

dfWithMonth.show(5)

%pyspark
dfGroupByMonth = dfWithMonth.groupBy("Month").sum()
dfGroupByMonth.show(5)

%md 

## SQL queries over DataFrame


Dataframe provides a unified approach for data manipulation. It allows SQL style queries to be perform on the data residing in the dataframe with parallization mechanism.

Firstly, we need to register the dataframe as a temporary view.

msg.data:
SQL queries over DataFrame

Dataframe provides a unified approach for data manipulation. It allows SQL style queries to be perform on the data residing in the dataframe with parallization mechanism.

Firstly, we need to register the dataframe as a temporary view.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

dfDateParsed.createOrReplaceTempView("SingaporeCovid19")

sqlDF = spark.sql("SELECT * FROM SingaporeCovid19")
sqlDF.show()

%md 

With Zeppelin, we can write SQL directly into a cell. Executing an SQL cell gives us the results in table, or charts.

msg.data: With Zeppelin, we can write SQL directly into a cell. Executing an SQL cell gives us the results in table, or charts.

paragraphs.text:
%sql


Select * from SingaporeCovid19

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md ## Exericse 3 Using Spark SQL, generate a bar chart for `Discharged To Isolation` after 1st Mar 2020.
[Show Hint]
```sql Select Date, `Discharged To Isolation` from SingaporeCovid19 where Date >= '2020-03-01' -- In the `settings` dropdown, you might need to put `Date` in the `keys` field, and `Discharged To Isolation` to the `values` field. ```

paragraphs.text:
%md 


## User Defined Function (UDF)


In case we could not find the needed function in the library, we can define our user defined function.

msg.data:
User Defined Function (UDF)

In case we could not find the needed function in the library, we can define our user defined function.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

def isZero(s):
  return s == 0
  
spark.udf.register("isZero", isZero)

msg.data: <function isZero at 0x7f120169eb50>

paragraphs.text:
%sql

select `Daily Discharged`, isZero(`Daily Discharged`) From SingaporeCovid19

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

The above might return a `java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Unsupported class file major version 58` if we are using a JVM newer than version 11.

msg.data: The above might return a java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Unsupported class file major version 58 if we are using a JVM newer than version 11.

paragraphs.text:
%md

The UDFs are applicable to the dataframe methods such as `select`.

msg.data: The UDFs are applicable to the dataframe methods such as select.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

x = dfDateParsed.select(col("Daily Discharged"), isZero(col("Daily Discharged")))
x.show()

%md

For more about UDF, refer to https://docs.databricks.com/spark/latest/spark-sql/udf-python.html

msg.data: For more about UDF, refer to https://docs.databricks.com/spark/latest/spark-sql/udf-python.html
